page.title: 06WEASENHAM HALL
page.content: A large house or hall has been on this site since medieval times when the property belonged to John de Weasenham. The present hall was built at the direction of Lady Leicester in 1905. It is made of red brick in Tudor style with "Dutch" end gables on the top. The house was in disrepair when the present owners inherited it in 1957. They had the towers taken down and the lead sold which helped pay for the house to be renovated. It took two years to do the repairs. The central staircase was removed and a smaller one put in. Some ceilings were lowered and the house made more suitable for a family to live in. The house was saved from being demolished and it is hoped that the owner's family will continue to live there in years to come.
